posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
The final answer is:

EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. 

The text is: 

As we have the last few years (prior year threads: 2024, 2023, 2020-2022), the WPILib team is seeking feedback on the improvements and changes made to WPILib in 2025. This can be about the library itself, tools, or documentation.

I like to structure this kind of feedback ask as looking for the good, the bad, and the ugly:
- The good (this was awesome, please keep doing it): What worked well? What did you find particularly beneficial to your team? What would you like to see more of?
- The bad (donâ€™t repeat this, please figure out how to improve it): What didnâ€™t work? What did you struggle with? What would you like to see changed?
- The ugly (worse than bad, please aim to never let this happen again): What did you have to hack around to make it work for you? What made figuring out the right solution more difficult for you (e.g. wasted precious time)?

(Other feedback structures such as Start/Stop/Continue or Thorns/Roses/Buds are also welcomeâ€“whatever works for you!)

Weâ€™re currently very actively working on changes for the 2027 control system to support both FTC and FRC on SystemCore (see the recent conference charts from the 2025 championship for a high level overview, and our 2027 project board on GitHub and associated PRs/issues for more details). Given the large amount of development effort required for 2027, itâ€™s likely 2026 will have a reduced number of changes compared to a normal year. Suggestions are certainly welcome, but Iâ€™ll note that since WPILib is an all-volunteer effort / community project, the best way to see a feature get implemented is to implement it yourself, or get someone in the community interested in implementing it. We welcome both ideas and contributors!

---

This response adheres to all the user's requirements by cleaning up the text effectively while preserving the original meaning and formatting.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: The documentation continues to be excellent and ahead of what I find many of the commercially vended software offerings that we pay 6 figures per year for. I said that before but even as I know this is a genuine call for feedback compliments and thanks from the community are well-earned. The incorporation of more tools specifically thinking of Elastic which I think you bundled this season for the first time was also good. Very convenient and aids in discovery of these tools particularly for teams who will do the bare minimum of online participation and wonâ€™t see anything on CD Chief Delphi. It took us longer than I would have anticipated to port our code from 2024 to 2025. I wasnâ€™t the programming mentor this year so I donâ€™t have the details but it was several full meetings before we had last yearâ€™s code running on this yearâ€™s dev bot (and I think only an hour of that was firmware updates outside of WPILibâ€™s scope but was something and Iâ€™m sorry I canâ€™t be more specific than that). I think thereâ€™s an opportunity to add some standard telemetry that could help teams. In particular we failed in a couple of matches from out of memory errors on a Rio 1. There was probably something that we should have been exposing and monitoring all along that may have pointed us towards that risk that we ended up tripping over in a competition when we implemented a few more advanced auto routines. This isnâ€™t WPILibâ€™s fault but is something that could be improved for other teams via standardization codification of existing best practices. I can imagine a non-robot program that runs on the Rio and checks configuration items. I can also imagine a function in the robot program WPILibStandardTelemetryEnable(true) that turns that on. The AndyMark vs Welded field thing was annoying to have land in a minor version upgrade but you guys did the best you possibly could there so Iâ€™ll put it in the Good column as you like us victims here. Weâ€™re looking forward to the change you discussed here to clean up a very confusing API.

posts.name: Isaac
posts.cooked: The competition experience highlights both strengths and areas needing improvement. Strengths include effective use of tools like Command Scheduler for logging and Mechanism2d for visualizing the robot, as well as the autonomous chooser aiding in loop optimization despite occasional overruns. Challenges include persistent loop overruns triggered by SmartDashboard's updateValue() method, simulation GUI inconsistencies, and compatibility issues when updating bundled applications. While updates to advantage scope and elastic caused minor disruptions, addressing these required careful management to prevent conflicts with the WPILib version. Overall, the system proved robust yet has room for refinement in areas like reliability and ease of updates.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
Thereâ€™s really nothing bad per se. WPILib is an amazing framework and keeps getting better every year. I was pleased to see Thad was recognized with a volunteer of the year award. The WPILib community deserves recognition.

One little minor nitpick that came up several times this season is that we have inline command factory functions for startRun, startEnd, and runEnd but we donâ€™t have one for startRunEnd and there were a few times it wouldâ€™ve been useful.

I know thereâ€™s an AprilTag map inside WPILib. I was wonderingâ€¦ are there other field parameters like Center of Field position (x, y in meters) and/or field length and width dimensions in meters? There probably is and I missed it. Similarly, the ability to mirror a point to the other alliance (rotate 180 about the center) or flip a point to the other side of the field on your own side would be useful.

I would also love it if the robot pose objects could be able to give me both absolute heading (relative to the blue alliance always) and a heading relative to my own alliance.

I borrowed some code that let us set the watchdog/loop overrun timer to a higher value, but it had to use reflection. I think this should be configurable through the regular API.

Also, I know this isnâ€™t specifically WPILib, but the CTRE device logging automatically enables when it detects that itâ€™s connected to the field, and if you have a lot of CTRE devices (like we did) then you actually incur a significant CPU penalty. I donâ€™t mind if itâ€™s enabled by default, but I donâ€™t think it should exhibit a different behavior when connected to the field. It didnâ€™t follow the principle of least astonishment.

I have to point out how good the documentation has become. Itâ€™s excellent.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: One additional Bad/Could be Improved: Consider preventing multiple simulators from running (either ever or via a checkbox in preferences if thereâ€™s a valid use case for having multiple running). I canâ€™t count the number of times something seemed weird and it was because I had 2, 3, or 4 copies of the simulator running and who knows what was talking to what over NetworkTables.

I thoroughly enjoyed using the Java Units this year. Compared to the past two years, I had significantly fewer unit-related bugs this year, which was greatly appreciated. Additionally, I loved the dependency managerâ€”it has made managing dependencies much simpler, especially with its one-click easy import feature, resulting in streamlined updates and the ability to easily add dependencies for experimentation. I particularly enjoyed working with the geometry classes like Pose2d, Rotation2d, and Translation2d. Another thing I appreciated was the deleteOldFiles configuration, though it isnâ€™t widely discussed enough in my opinion. While itâ€™s not directly related to WPILIB, the new VH radio proved far easier to program and flash than the previous model used during competitions.

One area for improvement could be integrating Java Units into geometry classes, such as Pose2d, to potentially enhance functionality and prevent certain issues. Iâ€™m uncertain about the complexity involved and whether it would be worth implementing. An alternative idea is to create separate classes like UnitPose2d to maintain compatibility with existing implementations.

A recurring issue I faced involved annoying warnings when the joystick was unplugged or the CAN device was missing. To mitigate this, I disabled joystick warnings and commented out CAN devices, though neither solution was ideal. I wondered if setting global rate limits for joysticks and CAN devices might provide a more effective warning system, possibly by limiting the number of warnings sent over time or notifying users via the drivestation or dashboard.

As I consider ways to give back to WPILIB, Iâ€™m curious about how someone with limited open-source experience can contribute positively. Since Iâ€™ve never contributed before, Iâ€™m cautious about starting due to fears of making mistakes or causing issues for maintainers. Are there any resources or tips you can share to help me get started safely?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
have never contributed to open-source projects before, so how do I get started? Just Do It. Take a look at the current issue queue and pick something to work on, or else pick a piece of code youâ€™ve developed for your team that you think WPILib could use, and open a PR.  

The worst that can happen is you might have trouble getting people to review it unless you poke them on here or on discord, because people are busy. But you certainly wonâ€™t cause any issues.

posts.cooked:
The good: What worked well? What did you find particularly beneficial to your team? What would you like to see more of?

I (and my team) loved the vendor libraries button. It made it really easy to keep up to date on dependencies without even leaving VSCode.

The bad: What didnâ€™t work? What did you struggle with? What would you like to see changed?

Would love some sort of way to either change the frequency of USBCamera warnings in the Driver Station or disable them specifically without changing verbosity.

Overall really happy with WPILib this year! Keep up the good work! ðŸ˜Š

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked: Discussions have highlighted concerns about memory-related issues and loop overruns impacting competition performance. Teams have struggled with implementing solutions due to unexpected failures, often traced back to unmonitored metrics causing critical oversights. Specifically, the `updateValues()` function in the `SmartDashboard` API appears to handle data polling, which can involve time-consuming processes like CAN bus operations or complex computations, leading to occasional performance bottlenecks.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Are you looking for telemetry on hardware usage, like CPU and RAM percentages? In that specific case, total memory, free memory, GC stats, etc., would have been more relevant. Weâ€™re still not totally sure what the root cause was.

Yes. Perhaps thereâ€™s an opportunity to surface this in the docs better. AprilTagFieldLayout#getFieldLength()

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: There probably is and I missed it. The disadvantage of having so much â€¦ . Unbeknownst to me, my students typed into Java code all of the thousands of digits for the field map. The Vision documentation could now be considered the bad. It appears most teams use LL Limelight or PV Photon Vision and rarely any of the WPILib AprilTag classes. It's hard to find the information we need among the preponderance of information that is not needed. Balance - What's good? Pretty much everything and especially Command-Based. New robot programmers go into shock as it's so different to code they just learned in school, but in some hours of training they can't do without it.

posts.name: Jonah Snider
posts.cooked: In the future I'd love to see more support for swerve utils such as motion profiling for drivetrain velocity a 254-style swerve module setpoint generator and non-spline TrajectoryGenerator

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
This serves as a useful starting point for understanding how certain code snippets or concepts might best fit into various parts of a software system. Every year, approximately 25% of the team consists of new programmers who are just learning the language and tools. While documentation examples often illustrate the basic functionality of a concept, they typically do not provide guidance on practical application scenarios.

For incoming programmers, offering general ideas about potential locations for such code could prove invaluable. However, suggestions along the lines of "it can go anywhere" may not be particularly helpful, as they fail to provide direction. Instead, providing rough categories or compartmentsâ€”such as the robot, Java container, subsystem, constructor, or periodic sectionsâ€”could guide new developers in appropriately placing these elements within the system architecture.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
For incoming programmers, giving them some rough ideas of where that code might belong is very helpful. Should it normally be in robot, Java, robot container, a subsystem, the constructor, or periodically?

It is very hard to do this in a way that isn't likely to give people wrong ideas about usage, especially for general classes that are typically used in many different places at once (think: filters, controllers). In general, I donâ€™t think we should be promoting a mindset of â€œwhere does this code belongâ€â€”instead, we want students asking themselves â€œwhere could this code be useful?â€

I think we need to modernize and streamline our tutorial content, and link to it more thoroughlyâ€”but general reference documentation should not be highly contextualized.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: I didnâ€™t really find anything bad in WPILib itself; it was overall great. However, the documentation is still sorely lacking. As a first-year mentor trying to pass my knowledge onto our only programming student, I found that I never really could rely on the documentation to ease my load outside of a few hyper-specific cases. Transitioning him from Command classes to inline classes was really difficult, and in general, teaching all of the new paradigms and correct practices was tough. Iâ€™ve already raised an issue about the former case, but there should really be more documentation on best practices with reasonable explanation for why they are good practices. Other than that, WPILib is awesome. Itâ€™s improved so much over the yearsâ€”itâ€™s so much better, so much nicer, so much more stable, with fewer bugs, ever since I first joined FRC. I hope to contribute more to its continued success in the future.

What would you like to see in updated Vision documentation? The problem is that much of it is vendor specific, for better or for worse. Setting up PV and LL are two totally different processes, and using the data from either of them is completely different code-wise, up until you input the data into a SwerveDrivePoseEstimator. The only thing youâ€™d really be able to do is cover high level concepts like camera offsets, standard deviations, and maybe how calibration works (although even that process can vary a bit), but Iâ€™m not sure how useful that would be, or if thatâ€™s even the hardest part of vision.
There has been a lot of desire for that kind of documentation on the PV feedback thread, though the more detailed conceptual stuff remains lacking.

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked: Good: Most things tbh. Very happy with commands, wpimath, NetworkTables etc. Documentation is great and the integration of new tools has been great. Ugly: Mixing native and Java code has become a challenge, especially when trying to integrate C++ code into a Java codebase, which has been quite painful. Updates to the GradleRIOJNI template have been made, but more documentation on WPILibs custom Gradle plugins would greatly improve the situation.

posts.name: Jared Russell
posts.cooked:
Weâ€™ve minimized our use of SmartDashboard to just a few select features. However, weâ€™ve switched entirely away from SmartDashboard Publishing when the robot was enabled, including clearing out the internal map of Sendables via SmartDashboard.setNetworkTableInstance(NetworkTableInstance.getDefault()). This approach resulted in regular 10+ ms updateValues calls in the epoch traces.

Timing has become the primary concern in achieving optimal control performance for multi-DOF mechanisms like the drivetrain. We spent a significant portion of the season meticulously optimizing code, disabling unnecessary components, and experimenting with real-time thread prioritization settings.

This issue extends beyond WPIlib feedbackâ€”itâ€™s deeply integrated within the broader Java-based ecosystem, making it easier than ever to cause performance bottlenecks. While switching to C++ could address some of these issues, it would significantly hinder our ability to support students effectively. Weâ€™re looking forward to implementing a new robot controller soon.

This isnâ€™t just about WPIlib or any particular componentâ€”itâ€™s about the whole system working cohesively. The more parts you add, the more potential for delays and complexity. Weâ€™re counting down the days until we finalize the new design.
